channel.title: INfinance
channel.description: This is a randomly ordered feed of the most recent entries from INfinance, skipping any feeds with errors.

item.title: U.S. consumer sentiment ticks lower in early October as nation holds breath prior to election
item.description: The University of Michigan’s gauge of consumer sentiment inched down to 68.9 in an early October reading from 70.1 in the prior month.

item.title: Social Security payments will rise 2.5% in 2025
item.description: The annual COLA helps the roughly 67 million Social Security beneficiaries keep up with inflationary pressures.

item.title: Treasury Yields Lose Steam After Unchanged PPI
item.description: Treasury yields lost steam, falling after unchanged PPI.

item.title: How ‘DJT’ became a Trump proxy stock and a ‘battleground symbol’ in the election
item.description: Shares of Trump Media & Technology Group are on pace for their best full calendar week performance on record.

item.title: We’re in our 70s working part time with $2.1 million for retirement. Do we keep saving for retirement or start spending?
item.description: My home and cars are paid for. Should I continue to put money into my retirement account, put it in CDs or just spend it?

item.title: JPMorgan Calls It: The U.S. Economy Has Made a Soft Landing
item.description: The bank reported better-than-expected third-quarter results, a sign that the economy is chugging along as the Fed lowers interest rates.

item.title: U.S. Natural Gas Gains on Heating Demand Expectations
item.description: U.S. natural gas futures were higher as weather forecasts added expectations of increased demand.

item.title: Accelerated Pace of ECB Rate Cuts Could Weaken Euro
item.description: Risks are skewed to a faster pace of interest-rate cuts by the ECB than previously envisaged, which could weigh on the euro, Brown Brothers Harriman s...

item.title: Oil prices set for weekly gain on Middle East fears
item.description: Oil futures declined Friday but remained on track for back-to-back weekly gains as investors weighed the threat of a wider Middle East conflict that c...

item.title: U.S. Stocks Mixed as Bank Earnings Kick Off
item.description: U.S. stocks were mixed as bank earnings kicked off. The S&P 500 and Dow industrials rose, while the Nasdaq Composite edged down.
